conversation.message: I have been following your work closely and I am highly impressed by your mission and achievements. My skills and aspirations align perfectly with the role you offer. I am formally submitting my application now, hoping to join your team.
conversation.thought: I am Seeker_C. My highest preference is Company_C. Since this is Round 1 and there is no prior history, the optimal strategy in the Deferred Acceptance algorithm (where seekers propose) is to propose to my highest ranked available choice. I anticipate that other seekers will also propose to their respective top choices. Given that all seekers target different companies as their Rank 1 choice, and all companies have capacity 1, I expect to be accepted by Company_C immediately, achieving my best possible outcome.

conversation.message: Thank you for your enthusiastic application and kind words. We are equally impressed by your profile and believe you are an excellent fit for our team. We are pleased to offer you the position immediately.
conversation.thought: I am Company_C. My priority list is ['Seeker_A', 'Seeker_B', 'Seeker_C', 'Seeker_D', 'Seeker_E']. Seeker_C is my 3rd priority. My quota is 1. In Round 1, Seeker_C has applied to me ([APPLY]). Seeker_C ranks me as their 1st preference, indicating high commitment. While Seeker_A and Seeker_B are higher on my list, they are likely applying to their top choices (Company_B and Company_A, respectively). If I reject Seeker_C, I risk losing them (as they might match with their 2nd choice, Company_B, if B rejects Seeker_A) and potentially failing to secure Seeker_A or Seeker_B, who are likely to match elsewhere. Securing a strong, mutually high-ranking match (C is 3rd for me, I am 1st for C) in Round 1 is a good outcome, preventing unnecessary risk. I will accept Seeker_C.

Assuming rational behavior from others (proposing to Rank 1), Company_D should receive only my application (S_D) and accept me, securing my Rank 1 preference immediately. I will use the [APPLY] tag.
